thread.title: Northwest Missouri forced five turnovers to rout archrival Pitt State
thread.title_full: Northwest Missouri forced five turnovers to rout archrival Pitt State

author: Jeremy Deckard
title: Northwest Missouri forced five turnovers to rout archrival Pitt State
text:
Northwest Missouri forced five turnovers to rout archrival Pitt State No. 3 Bearcats earn 31-14 victory at Pittsburg Posted: October 17, 2015 - 6:47pm By Jeremy Deckard The Capital-Journal 
PITTSBURG — A dominating first-half defensive performance at its archrival’s home field helped Northwest Missouri avenge a home loss from a season ago. 
The No. 3 Bearcats scored a defensive touchdown and forced five turnovers en route to a 31-14 victory over Pittsburg State on Saturday in a matchup of Top 25 teams at Carnie Smith Stadium. 
It was the first regular season game played between the MIAA rivals in Pittsburg since 2001. The two teams played an annual game at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Mo., from 2002-2013. The Gorillas knocked off the Bearcats 35-17 last season in Maryville, Mo. 
George Sehl caught two touchdowns for Northwest Missouri (7-0) and the Bearcat defense held the Gorillas (4-3) to just 175 yards of total offense and forced seven Gorilla punts. 
“Any time a defense can force five turnovers in game, it’s going to be huge for us as an offense,” Sehl said. “Any time you can come into this type of hostile environment and win you are doing something right.” 
Sehl, a junior transfer from Iowa Western Community College, caught a 3-yard touchdown from Brady Bolles on the Bearcats’ first possession. But Pittsburg State tied the game on its following possession when Marques Cushon threw a 19-yard pass to Kyle Swartz after taking the handoff on an end-around. The Gorillas’ scoring drive was aided by a personal foul facemask call on the Bearcats. 
Northwest Missouri controlled the clock for more than seven minutes on its second possession. Bolles finished a 19-play scoring drive with a 3-yard touchdown to sophomore tight end Clayton Wilson. The Bearcats then scored defensively with Brandon Yost recovering a fumble in the end zone. 
Yost, a senior from Omaha, Neb., finished the game with four total tackles (one for loss), a pass breakup, and the recovered fumble for a touchdown. 
“We just played relentless all day,” Yost said. “We didn’t have a doubt in our mind that we could come out here today and do what we needed to do. We buckled down, trusted each other and came out with a victory.” 
Sehl would score on a 68-yard catch and complete a 21-0 scoring run in the second quarter as the Bearcats took a 28-7 lead into halftime. 
Pittsburg State entered the game second in the MIAA averaging 247.5 yards rushing per game, but were held for minus-three yards rushing in the first half and just 80 yards rushing for the game. 
The Gorillas played without starting quarterback John Roderique who missed the game with an unspecified foot injury. Sophomore backup Thomas LePage rushed for 27 yards and threw for 76 yards and a touchdown. LePage was intercepted four times by the Northwest Missouri defensive unit, with Kevin Berg hauling in two of those picks. 
With the win, Northwest Missouri now leads the all-time series between the two programs 25-24. 
Northwest Missouri will continue MIAA play Oct. 24 with a home game against Fort Hays State, while the Gorillas will travel to Nebraska-Kearney. 
Northwest Mo. (7-0) 7 21 0 3 — 31 
Pittsburg St. (4-3) 7 0 7 0 — 14 
NWM — Sehl 3 pass from Bolles (Mathiesen kick) 
PSU — Swartz 19 pass from Cushon (Levin kick) 
NWM — Wilson 5 pass from Bolles (Mathiesen kick) 
NWM — Yost 0 fumble return (Mathiesen kick) 
NWM — Sehl 68 pass from Schmidt (Mathiesen kick) 
PSU — Rose 15 pass from LePage (Levin kick) 
NWM — Matheisen 32 field goal
